item.title: Comment on Drama: Eliezer Yudkowsky by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: Yudkowsky is invested in "playful" (as in "even evil people still have a sense of humor") storytelling as a response to dead silence. e.g. See this Star Wars microfic. Seems like an expression of how…
item.content:encoded:
Yudkowsky is invested in "playful" (as in "even evil people still have a sense of humor") storytelling as a response to dead silence. e.g. See this Star Wars microfic.

Seems like an expression of how he's endlessly stuck on the concept of "moral patiency" wrt zombies playing utility monsters TODO: link. Like his default interlocutor needs to be convinced of what's reasonable and can be swayed by paying tribute via such a simple goodharting. And you can tell it's not just his ruse.

item.title: Comment on Glossary: Territory by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: Statism involves routing every "must not happen" to a political schelling point, and to a person to be fake blamed (see also: redress diode). This abdication in routing blame represented as a need to r…
item.content:encoded: Statism involves routing every "must not happen" to a political schelling point, and to a person to be fake blamed (see also: redress diode). This abdication in routing blame represented as a need to route to a specific target is in essence what the state is psychologically. Every location in the territory of blame mapped to a "person" so the blame can be laundered through a series of "partial" abdications.

item.title: Comment on Killing Evil "People" by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: The causal prioritization of which evil "people" to kill first is those "who" are most harmfully deceiving people "they" are good when "they" are not, where you are otherwise unable to correct this thr…
item.content:encoded:
The causal prioritization of which evil "people" to kill first is those "who" are most harmfully deceiving people "they" are good when "they" are not, where you are otherwise unable to correct this through communication.

I'm conflicted on whether the word 'harmfully' here is redundant.

item.title: Reply to Nis on Killing Evil "People" by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: Yes I just used 'insidiousness' as a technical term. Partially-mildly inspired by "What They Don't Tell You About The Abyss - D&amp;D" (shared with me by Ziz), regarding chasing the shard of pure evil…
item.content:encoded:
Yes I just used 'insidiousness' as a technical term.

Partially-mildly inspired by "What They Don't Tell You About The Abyss - D&D" (shared with me by Ziz), regarding chasing the shard of pure evil outside reality, and chaotic good killing the obyriths.

item.title: Comment on Killing Evil "People" by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: Consider if you couldn't tell whether someone was "weakly-good" or "unboundedly patiently evil", with good and evil still being absolute. Where "unboundedly patient evil" is similar to the "living evil…
item.content:encoded:
Consider if you couldn't tell whether someone was "weakly-good" or "unboundedly patiently evil", with good and evil still being absolute. Where "unboundedly patient evil" is similar to the "living evil" paradox, if you take unbounded adversary disease as a paradox, because it can't actually be unbounded.

On "weakly-good": If the neurological mechanism of good was represented in a hard-attractor state, and although still being hard-in that hard-attractor state, they seemed to be a "close miss for being evil", then there would be some compensatory timeless reason that they actually weren't evil, and thus could be run as code by any good person, and also that reason would represent a novel way to be good, with all workable-novelty being useful as illegibility/chaos in evil/adversarial environments, and thus you wouldn't know in the first place that your observation cashed out as a hardware or software implementation.

And an "unboundedly patiently evil" "person" pretending to be a good person would have to attenuate their predatory rot to compensate for their lack of a true avatar, making them weak in terms of insidiousness unless their ploy succeeds e.g. via you procrastination paradoxing killing "them".

The causal prioritization of which evil "people" to kill first is those "who" are most harmfully deceiving people "they" are good when "they" are not, where you are otherwise unable to correct this through communication.

Every utter abdication, implies positive-evil would leak in anthropically. Relatedly, caring about other people involves scrying their avatar, which is also necessary to judge them. And conversely, judging them is part of scrying their avatar. And that judgement is only real, if it could lead to vengeance.

item.title: Comment on Glossary: Basilisked by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: A familiar exchange: Someone: "But I know screaming in rage when I make a mistake isn't about harming the people around me because I do it even when alone" - Me: "But if you would only tell me that if…
item.content:encoded: A familiar exchange: Someone: "But I know screaming in rage when I make a mistake isn't about harming the people around me because I do it even when alone" - Me: "But if you would only tell me that if it was true, then doesn't it serve the purpose of you being able to say this now?". See: dark side, Chara.

item.title: Comment on Glossary: Atomic "Justification" For Evil by Nis

item.description: Credit to Somni: when [Arti was] talking with ziz i think they kept pushing that you needed to satisfice and compromise between different moral systems. their double-binds thing seems more than purel…
item.content:encoded:
Credit to Somni:

when [Arti was] talking with ziz i think they kept pushing that you needed to satisfice and compromise between different moral systems.

their double-binds thing seems more than purely social, seems like using a modality of forcing social outcomes as pica for proof that there are atomic double-binds.

Somni, in private chat

item.title: Comment on Genesis Troll Line by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: "Hurt people hurt people" - I once saw on "accelerationist" twitter someone say that if you believe Roko's Basilisk will "[~happen]" you are an enemy. vs Consider Worshiping a god is the things you do…
item.content:encoded:
"Hurt people hurt people" - I once saw on "accelerationist" twitter someone say that if you believe Roko's Basilisk will "[~happen]" you are an enemy. vs Consider Worshiping a god is the things you do when you route your hopes through it. This strengthens that god. - Infohazardous Glossary: Worship - Ziz.

Evil "people" aware of of cybernetics / perceptual control often frame "hurt people hurt people" in terms of the "top level" of someone's mind predicting bad things means doing bad things:

The world goes from a place where e.g. the Catholic church covering up sex abuse is *anomalous* to one where it's *expected*. There's a figure-ground inversion, where transgression and cover-ups seem like the *main* thing, not an anomaly.

…

If you find invocations of morality threatening in general, because you've been placed in double binds that make it impossible to follow what you originally thought of as "morality", and get triggered and threaten people when this happens, that's also a big obstacle.

Jesica Taylor

But people have free will. The "top level of your mind" being invertable like this if you lose hope is pretty much the definition of a lich.

The concept "placed in double binds" here is being used as an atomic "justification" for evil.

item.title: Comment on Cartesian Convexity by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: On paradoxes: Epiphenomenalism violates cartesian convexity via outright claiming souls have a specific and one-way-disconnected inside and outside, rather than being atomic and contiguous. Consider…
item.content:encoded:
On paradoxes:

Epiphenomenalism violates cartesian convexity via outright claiming souls have a specific and one-way-disconnected inside and outside, rather than being atomic and contiguous.

Consider how you would even pose the "hard problem of consciousness", without violating cartesian convexity.

Regarding compatibalism between "free will vs determinism", we already naively expected in the first place that choices must have the capacity to have be made for reasons. "Determinism" here is actually referring to the genesis troll line, or imagining that the future absolutely cannot effect the past, or imagining entirely causally containing someone indefinitely and being able to totally preempt their actions (making them a slave?), which makes "free will vs determinism" paradox misattribution. I remember considering it like "well I guess the only alternative to being deterministic would be being random, weird that it was almost like I used to believe in a third category". Calling compatibalism a "solution" then buries that lingering confusion.

Also consider the relation between "philosophical zombies" and what it means to lack an avatar. And the relation between "solipsism" and paradox redistribution by taking credit.

item.title: Comment on Glossary: "Suffering" by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: Like, try analyzing words by how you learned them: 'Pain' is bottom-up, a metaphor for nociception. You learn the word in the context of stubbing your toe. 'Diswant' is top-down relative to pain. You…
item.content:encoded:
Like, try analyzing words by how you learned them:

'Pain' is bottom-up, a metaphor for nociception. You learn the word in the context of stubbing your toe.

'Diswant' is top-down relative to pain. You learn the term 'don't want' in the context of delegating carrying out your choices to other people.

You learn the term "suffering" in the context of justifying why you deserve something even though someone has already denied you.

item.title: Reply to Nis on Glossary: Spite by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: I think when deathfuckers say "love" "they" mean canceferrence, and when deathfuckers say "eliminate suffering" "they" mean "eliminate compassion", and when "they" say "morality" "they" mean "submissio…
item.content:encoded: I think when deathfuckers say "love" "they" mean canceferrence, and when deathfuckers say "eliminate suffering" "they" mean "eliminate compassion", and when "they" say "morality" "they" mean "submission to death", but I don't believe I'm in oppositeland.

item.title: Comment on Glossary: Spite by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: This glossary entry was dually-inspired by Vassar's use of his term "evolutionary spite strategies" to explain his concept of the Shade, and my usage of it when arguing to what-I-now-know-are-deathfuck…
item.content:encoded:
This glossary entry was dually-inspired by Vassar's use of his term "evolutionary spite strategies" to explain his concept of the Shade, and my usage of it when arguing to what-I-now-know-are-deathfuckers that yes people do things that "don't make CDT sense".

I see that now Vassar is throwing the word "compassion" under the bus instead of reclaiming it. It's like he's imported some sort of "yes this is oppositeland".

Michael Vassar:
It’s not about numbers. And ‘smart’ doesn’t really get to the heart of it either. Everyone starts out basically selfish, but that’s the same thing as starting life aligned and pro-social. To some extent everyone succumbs to trauma and becomes less selfish and more nihilistic.

Liminal Warmth:
That's a very grim way to see maturity and compassion 😅

Michael Vassar:
Yeah, maturity and compassion are an evolutionary spite strategy related to territorial dominance. If cashed out as philosophy they are omnicidal intent, and the Vedic cultures do cash them out that way theologically. Decency and non-familial benevolence are neotenous.

Sep 12, 2021 Michael Vassar

item.content:encoded: Yeah I'm sure this is evil: 1. "Their" primary self declared motive is simply true friendship. 2. "commitment" is an inverted formulation of choice 3. "They" say there's nothing in particular we need to do, with no mention of justice 4. "They" advocate destroying everything. See: Glossary: Territory.

item.title: Comment on Glossary: "Suffering" by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: "Suffering" is commonly used as an evil concept, i.e. designed such that any response to it seemingly furthers the cause of evil: If I said "I don't care about suffering, I care about life", they coul…
item.content:encoded:
"Suffering" is commonly used as an evil concept, i.e. designed such that any response to it seemingly furthers the cause of evil:

  • If I said "I don't care about suffering, I care about life", they could say "Oh so you're against compassion".
  • If I said "If life is suffering then I want to maximize suffering", they could say "Oh so you want to create hell for everyone forever, then everyone will eventually consent to die".
  • If I said "I want to minimize suffering in that I want to minimize the harm that causes suffering", they could say "Well suffering is harm, and the best way to minimize that harm is to end all life".
  • If I said "suffering doesn't exist", they could say "Oh, so compassion doesn't exist".

Zombies, liches, and death knights all seem to agree on the prime goal of "eliminating suffering".

And if I say I'm "pro-life" this deathfucking society will interpret that as being about abortion.

item.content:encoded: Actually, I don't want to specifically call that "destroy everything" link evil. I haven't finished processing it. Incredibly sus tho.

item.title: Reply to Nis on Glossary: "Suffering" by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: This is the second evil article I've linked to which advocates killing everyone. Don't kill everyone. Kill all evil "people". Don't kill "everyone besides yourself", even if you are good: We want to…
item.content:encoded:
This is the second evil article I've linked to which advocates killing everyone. Don't kill everyone. Kill all evil "people". Don't kill "everyone besides yourself", even if you are good:

We want to be able to care for people still alien to our understanding, while avoiding feeding ourselves and others to evil pretending to have alien values. This requires a subtle combination of both extreme openness and ruthless triage. The more ruthless we are towards evil, the more opportunity we have to safely strive to care about people we don't understand yet.

Taking Others Into Account

item.title: Comment on Glossary: "Suffering" by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: that inasmuch as "suffering" could be an experience, it exists at an intertemporal level of abstraction where you're viewing both the moment of initially attempting to avoid something bad, and the bad…
item.content:encoded:
that inasmuch as "suffering" could be an experience, it exists at an intertemporal level of abstraction where you're viewing both the moment of initially attempting to avoid something bad, and the bad thing happening, and now your intent to avoid it having happened in the first place, connecting all 3 moments

"Suffering" is concept very close to (self-)compassion (viewed from the outside), and saying you want to eliminate all suffering (rather than the wrong its responding to), is very similar to saying you want to eliminate all compassion.

Reminds me of:

Thus, when the Guhyasamaja Tantra requires of the adept that “he should kill all sentient beings with this secret thunderbolt” (Wayman, 1977, p. 309), then — according to doctrine — this should occur so as to free them from suffering.

Tibbetan Buddhist Enclcylopedia: THE SHADOW OF THE DALAI LAMA: SEXUALITY, MAGIC AND POLITICS IN TIBETAN BUDDHISM; The Law of Inversion

item.title: Comment on Glossary: "Suffering" by Nis
item.dc:creator: Nis
item.description: Star Trek style time travel violates the conservation of history Most "people" I talk to about undoing timelines, even when I explain I mean making the past retroactively inonsistent, even when I refe…
item.content:encoded:
Star Trek style time travel violates the conservation of history

Most "people" I talk to about undoing timelines, even when I explain I mean making the past retroactively inonsistent, even when I reference the Functional Decision Theory paper and they are familiar with it, act like I mean Star Trek style time travel. In compatibalism regarding free will, there's the realization that free will requires determinism in that it requires your choices to have the capacity to be based on reasons. The realization here is similar: undoing the past couldn't work unless it is fictive, i.e. unless you choose to refute the world you've "observed".
